channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Developer who wants to learn Scala and NodeJS - West London
item.description: Love Perl but want to skill-up on another stack at your employerâ€™s expense?

item.title: Do you love customers? Senior Perl Developer with a product focus, London
item.description: Ever find yourself wishing you could see meaningful impact on users from your work? Trapped in a company with long release cycles and dubious release dates? Wish your ideas for product improvement didnâ€™t keep disappearing in to the Project Managerâ€™s backlog?

Great modules released last week;

StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Using Rakudo Perl 6 in a Docker container
item.description: Short examples.

item.title: 2018.23 Opened/Closed
item.description: The weekly awesome.

item.title: Faster dispatches with MoarVM specializer plugins
item.description: Part of the Performance and Reliability grant is to speed up private method calls in roles, as well as assignments in to Scalar containers. It turns out they need the same mechanism in MoarVM to work.

item.title: SQLite in Memory
item.description: A simple example in Perl using an in-memory version of SQLite for when you'd like to use SQL statements, but don't need to store the data on the disk.

item.title: Grant Extension Request: Maintaining the Perl 5 Core (Tony Cook)
Grant Report : May, 2018. Second month of the grant.

Maintaining the Perl 5 Core (Dave Mitchell): Grant Report for May 2018
Maintaining Perl 5 (Tony Cook): May 2018 Grant Report
DBD::Oracle Trial release
item.description: It is still marked as 'unauthorized', but if you use Oracle with Perl, you'd better test it now, before it becomes official.

item.title: CPANRatings going read-only
item.description: It is hardly used and MetaCPAN is expected to add a similar feature, so it is time to retire CPAN Ratings.

item.title: What's new on CPAN - May 2018
item.description: The usual monthly handpicked list of interesting modules on CPAN.

item.title: A very easy way to create XML
item.description: Treat XML as easily as JSON using XML::MyXML.

item.title: Update to XPath Sandbox
item.description: The XPath Sandbox tool allows you to try out different XPath expressions directly in your browser. Some new additions arrived now.

item.title: Do you want to make your developers faster?
item.description: Introduce testing. Set up Continuous Integration. Refactor your code. Gabor, the editor of the Perl Weekly, can help you with any of these in Perl, Python, and other languages. Even remotely.

item.title: Why Programmers Use the Test Hierarchy Antipattern
item.description: I think the key is 'Test inheritance should only be used to meet the needs of the tests, not the needs of the code under test.'

item.title: Building a Geo-Coding Database and Website
item.description: Mapping places to coordinates including a sample web application.

item.title: What is a Bool?
item.description: Perl will treat any value either as 'true' or 'false', so what does the keyword 'Bool' really mean in Moose? Mostly 0 and 1, but it also allows overloading boolification for false.

item.title: Why is parsing considered solved?
item.description: A short history of 'language' and linguistics.

item.title: Baby Moose
item.description: This week it is the turn of the Baby Moose. The saga continues.

item.title: Simple Linux Screenshot Application in Perl
item.description: Saif shows Using the world's simplest GUI generator

item.title: #359 - CPANRatings going read-only
item.description:
Hi there,

In 2 weeks search.cpan.org will shut down. All the links will redirect to the appropriate pages on MetaCPAN. Soon after that Google will take the pages of s.c.o. out of their index and MetaCPAN will become the leading result on Google and elsewhere in a few weeks. Or so I hope.

In addition, as we just learned, CPANRatings is going to become read-only and MetaCPAN will soon have a replacement service.

Exiting times as MetaCPAN will suddenly have 3 times its current traffic.

This would be a great time to start contributing to MetaCPAN to improve its search results and whatever you think could work better. You could even build an alternative UI in plain JavaScript. If you'd like to know how, send me and email!

In any case, enjoy your week!
